titleStmt.title: The effect of Ti on the sintering and mechanical properties of refractory high-entropy alloy Ti x WTaVCr fabricated via spark plasma sintering for fusion plasma-facing materials

analytic.title: The effect of Ti on the sintering and mechanical properties of refractory high-entropy alloy Ti x WTaVCr fabricated via spark plasma sintering for fusion plasma-facing materials

biblStruct.note: Received 26 March 2017 Received in revised form 9 June 2017 Accepted 25 June 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Plasma-facing materials High-entropy alloy Tungsten Hardness Compressive strength

div.p: The synthesis and characterization of Ti x WTaVCr alloys for high-temperature and fusion plasma-facing applications are presented in this study. Specimens of Ti x WTaVCr containing 0 to 7 at% Ti were prepared via spark plasma sintering of an elemental powder mixture at 1500 C. Characterization of sintered samples via X-ray diffraction and scanning electron microscopy with energy dispersive spectroscopy revealed increased formation of a BCC solid solution due to the addition of up to 7 at% Ti. Mechanical characterizations of the Ti x WTaVCr alloys indicate that they are harder and stronger than several reported high-entropy alloys. The alloy that contained 7 at% Ti also exhibited improved oxidation resistance in air at 1000 C. Its improved strength, hardness, and oxidation resistance suggest future applications for this high-entropy alloy in high-temperature and nuclear applications.

Reaction sintering of powder mixture was used to develop refractory HEA. The increase in Ti content produces W-rich and near equiatomic BCC phases. Ti x WTaVCr shows superior mechanical properties than several other HEAs. The Ti x WTaVCr sample having 7 at.% Ti also shows better oxidation resistant.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Fusion power plants will require innovative materials to withstand unforeseen thermo-mechanical loads and irradiation. These transient conditions will expose the critical components of fusion reactors to unique service environments [1]. For example, the heat load on the ITER diverter may rise as high as 40 MJ/m 2 [2]. Therefore, innovative high-temperature and plasma-facing materials are required.

Tungsten (W) is an effective future fusion application material, as it exhibits a refractory nature along with low erosion, suppressed tritium retention, and reduced neutron activation [3]. The obstacles to the use of W include radiation-induced embrittlement and its high ductile-to-brittle transition temperature [3]. Its loss of strength and volatile oxidation above ~1000 C [4] also limit its applications as the temperature on the diverter surface is expected to reach ~1100 C under transient conditions [5]. These constraints justify further research. Consequently, several W-based binary alloys such as W-Re [6], W-Ta [7], W-V [8], W-Ti [9], W-Mo [10], and W-Cr [11] have been studied. However, each of these alloys exhibits a number of shortcomings.

High-entropy alloys (HEAs) have several characteristics that are better than those of conventional alloys. These include high mechanical strength, hardness, and thermal stability, along with good corrosion, oxidation, and creep resistances [12]. This suggests that they may be effective in high-temperature and plasma-facing applications [13]. The development of W-containing, refractory, highentropy alloys with enhanced properties such as MoNbTaW, MoNbTaVW [14], and other refractory HEAs including CrMo 0.5 Nb-Ta 0.5 TiZr, Cr x NbTiV y Zr [13], CrNbTiVZr, CrNbTiZr [12] and TaNbHfZrTi [13], produced by methods such as arc melting [15], conventional sintering [16], physical vapor deposition [17], and mechanical alloying [18] have been reported. However, current research lacks information about high-entropy alloys that consist of refractory metals with the low neutron activation properties necessary to minimize hazards from the irradiated materials, and thus enable maintenance and recycling [19]. This paper presents reduced-activation Ti x WTaVCr alloys developed via elemental powder mixing followed by spark plasma sintering.

Owing to the segregation that occurs during melting [20], porosity from conventional sintering [21], thickness limits associated with physical vapor deposition [17], and contamination and oxidation [22] from mechanical alloying, elemental powders were mixed in a Turbula shaker mixer. The mixture was sintered into high-density bulk samples in a few minutes via spark plasma sintering (SPS), which offers short soaking times and high heating and cooling rates [23].

The constituent elements were carefully selected to provide compositions with reduced activation behaviors. The purpose of this was to minimize activation of the alloys due to exposure to the neutron fluxes produced in deuterium-tritium fusion reactions [24]. W, Ta, V, Cr, and Ti were used to develop HEAs that combine strength with irradiation and oxidation resistances, while ensuring reduced activation properties [25]. However, enough Ti content was provided for solid solution formation to avoid significant reductions in mechanical properties [26]. The development of Ti x WTaVCr and the effect of Ti addition are presented in this paper.

div.head: Experimental
div.p: To fabricate the Ti x WTaVCr samples, 99.9% pure W (1.21 mm from Daegu Tek. Co.), V, Cr, Ti (<75 mm, 63 mm, and 45 mm, respectively, from Kojundo Korea) and Ta (<45 mm, from Seo Gwang Metal) powders were mixed using a Turbular shaker-mixer in plastic vials at 30 RPM for up to 3 h. Steel balls were added in a 1:1 ratio with the powder to ensure rigorous mixing. SPS (SPS, Dr. Sintering SPS-515S, Japan) was carried out in a carbon felt-covered graphite mold to prevent heat loss [37]. Prior to sintering at 1500 C, the 1300 C and 1400 C sintering temperatures were also tested. A temperature of 1500 C and axial pressure of 50 MPa were applied in a vacuum (10 À3 torr) for up to 10 min. The detailed sintering process and size of sintered samples are shown in Fig. 1.

Gas fusion analysis (ONH-2000 & CS-2000, ELTRA, Germany) and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, iCAP 6300 Duo, Thermo Scientific Co., UK) were performed to determine the actual compositions of the alloy samples.

Archimedes' principle was used to measure density. The crystallographic and microscopic characteristics of the samples were studied via X-ray diffraction (XRD, D/MAX-2500, RIGAKU, USA), scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Magellan 400, USA), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM2100F, JEOL Ltd., Japan). The chemical homogeneity and phase content were analyzed via energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS, FEI Magellan 400, USA). Electron probe microanalysis (EPMA 1610, AE11, Shimadzu, Japan) was performed to determine the compositions of various phases.

Disk-shaped sintered samples were cut through their crosssections for micro-Vickers hardness tests (402MVD, Wolpert Wilson Instruments, Germany). Room temperature compression tests on cylindrical samples with 6 mm in height and 4 mm in diameter were performed using an Instron 5982 (Instron, USA) machine with a strain rate of 10 À3 /s. A Gleeble 3500 (Dynamic Systems Inc., USA) system was used with cylindrical samples 6 mm in height and 3 mm in diameter for high-temperature (1200 C) compression tests in Ar at the same strain rate (10 À3 /s). Thermogravimetric analyses were performed to determine sample weight gain during oxidation at 1000 C in air for up to 3 h. The oxidized samples were examined via XRD and SEM-EDS for oxide layer characterization.

div.head: Results and discussion
div.p: Prior to the fabrication of bulk samples, the sintering process was optimized. SPS under 50 MPa axial pressure revealed improved in density from ~79% to ~95% with increasing sintering temperature from 1300 C to 1500 C, respectively. Further increase in temperature can increase the contamination from graphite mold. Therefore, fabrication of samples was carried out at 1500 C sintering temperature for detailed characterization which is given in following sections.

div.head: Compositional analysis
div.p: ICP-OES chemical analysis reveals very little change in composition after spark plasma sintering, as observed in Table 1. Sintered samples containing 0 at%, 4 at%, and 7 at% Ti have been labeled 0Ti s , 4Ti s , and 7Ti s , respectively. These notations are used in the remainder of this paper.

SPS in graphite molds causes carbon to enter sintered samples [27]. Via gas fusion analysis, 0.79 wt%, 0.83 wt%, and 0.76 wt% Please cite this article in press as: O.A. Waseem, et al., The effect of Ti on the sintering and mechanical properties of refractory high-entropy alloy Ti x WTaVCr fabricated via spark plasma sintering for fusion plasma-facing materials, Materials Chemistry and Physics (2017), http://dx.doi.org/ 10.1016/j.matchemphys.2017.06.054 carbon were detected in the 0Ti s , 4Ti s , and 7Ti s samples, respectively. Table 1 gives the relative densities of 0Ti s , 4Ti s , and 7Ti s . Clearly, Ti addition has a role in increasing the relative densities of the xTi s alloys.

div.head: Microstructural characterization
div.p: Fig. 2(a) and (b) show XRD patterns of the powdered (xTi p ) and sintered samples (xTi s ), respectively. Fig. 2(a) clearly shows separate peaks for all the elements in the powdered mixture. Reaction between the powders due to Ti addition is evident from Fig. 2(b). 0Ti s does not form a solid solution after sintering at 1500 C, and remains unalloyed even with the addition of 4 at% Ti. However, it converts into a BCC solid solution via a liquid phase sintering when the Ti content is increased to 7 at% (see pattern 7Ti s in Fig. 2(b)) [28]. The peaks from (110), (200), and (211) at 40 , 58 , and 73 , respectively indicate a BCC crystal structure similar to that of W in the majority of the sintered sample. Such patterns have been previously observed in refractory alloys [29] and HEAs [30,31].

The microstructures of the as-polished xTi s samples captured using backscattered electrons exhibit multiple phases (black, dark gray, and light gray) in a bright matrix. The elemental distribution determined via EDS reveals W, V, and Cr enrichment in various regions, as shown in Fig. S1 in Supplementary information. In addition, Ti-rich phases were observed in samples prepared with 4 at% and 7 at% Ti. The volume fractions of the Ti-rich phases must have been lower than the XRD detection limit, as no Ti-rich phase was observed in the XRD patterns [29].

The increase in microstructural homogeneity with the Ti content suggests that reaction between powders because of the formation of a liquid phase. This can be attributed to formation of localized Ti-Cr and Ti-Cr-V-based alloys, which melt at 1400e1600 C [32,33]. Therefore, localized melting enhances reaction between powders by accelerating diffusion [22]. Moreover, the relatively high Ti diffusion coefficient [28] also accounts for enhanced diffusion and sintering in Ti-bearing compositions. Reaction sintering is also evident from the increased density mentioned in Table 1.

EPMA was used to determine the chemical compositions of various phases observed via elemental mapping. The EPMA results are illustrated in Fig. 3. The EPMA and image analyses reveal ~43%, ~14%, and ~43% (by volume) W-, V-, and Cr-rich phases in the 0Ti s sample. The addition of 4 at% Ti produces a microstructure with ~31% Cr-and ~68% W-rich phases. Addition of 7 at% Ti increases the homogeneity of the microstructure, depletes the Cr-and V-rich phases and forms a BCC solid solution. The 7Ti s sample consists of ~56% near equiatomic single phase with 5 elements (the HEA condition) and ~43% W-rich phases. The remaining portions of the 4Ti s and 7Ti s samples consist of a dark black Ti-rich phase, as shown in Fig. 3. EBSD examinations were carried out to determine the effect of Ti addition on the grain size of the samples. As shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. S2 in Supplementary information, the average grain size decreases from 0Ti s to 7Ti s . The average grain size in sample with no Ti content is 4.64 mm. The 4 and 7 at.% addition of Ti, reduces the average grain size to 3.32 mm (in 4Ti s ) and 2.75 mm (in 7Ti s ), respectively. The detailed grain size distribution of xTi s samples are giving in Fig. S2 in Supplementary information.

The chemical natures of various regions determined via elemental mapping and EPMA, and shown in Fig. S1 in Supplementary information) and Fig. 3, respectively, were investigated via TEM-driven selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern analysis. The results are shown in Fig. 4.

Fig. 4 shows representative diffraction patterns obtained from the HEA, W-rich, Ti-rich, and Laves phases present in TEM samples prepared from 0Ti s , 4Ti s , and 7Ti s. The SAED pattern analysis of the near equiatomic single phase with 5 elements (the HEA condition) (point 1 in Fig. 4) indicates a BCC solid solution with a lattice parameter of 0.321 nm. The reflections from 111 in the W-rich phase (point 2 in Fig. 4) indicate a BCC crystal lattice with a lattice parameter of 0.323 nm.

The Ti-rich phase (point 3 in Fig. 4) is TiC, as it exhibits the expected FCC reflections with a lattice parameter of 0.423 nm. The highly exothermic heat of formation of TiC (À44.1 kcal/mol), and enhanced stability when compared to carbides of other constituent elements (W, Ta, V [34], and Cr [35]), favor TiC formation during sintering at 1500 C with heating rate of 100 C/min. Diffusion from the graphite mold to the samples during spark plasma sintering provides carbon for TiC formation [36]. The direct contact of the samples' surface with graphite mold forms a highly contaminated The TiC is considered beneficial for fusion applications as it improves resistance to irradiation and high heat fluxes [37]. The microstructural examination, as shown in Fig S3 in Supplementary information, reveals ~30-mm-thick layer of TiC on the surface, whereas uniformly distributed TiC phase, forms due to the diffusion of evaporated carbon [38], was observed in rest of the sample. The weight fractions of TiC, determined by assuming that all of the carbon introduced reacted with Ti, i.e., 0.15 wt% and 0.10 wt% in 4Ti s and 7Ti s , respectively. Those phases that are not equiatomic, W-rich, or Ti-rich, are expected to be intermetallic Laves phases as their SAED patterns do not match any of the standard BCC, FCC, or HCP reflections (represented by point 4 in Fig. 4). Laves phases are represented by the form AB2, where A is the element with the larger Gold-Schmidt radius and higher electro positivity [39]. These phases are very brittle [32] and are mostly observed from sintering with a low liquid phase content [40]. The possible Laves phases in a Ti-W-Ta-V-Cr system include TaV 2 (a ¼ 0.715 nm) [39], TiCr 2 (a ¼ 0.694 nm) [32], VTa 2 (a ¼ 0.75 nm) [41], TiV 2 (a ¼ 0.712 nm) [42], CrCr 2 (a ¼ 0.658 nm) [43], TaCr 2 (a ¼ 0.697 nm) [44], CrTa 2 (a ¼ 0.748 nm) [43], Ti(Cr,V) 2 (a ¼ 0.694 nm) [45], and (Ti,V)(V,Cr) 2 [45].

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: Hardness was assessed by subjecting the cross-sections of the sintered samples to the micro-Vickers hardness test. At least ten readings were taken to determine the representative hardnesses. As shown in Fig. 5(a), the hardness of 0Ti s is 714 HV, which is significantly higher than that of pure W. Adding up to 7 at% Ti converts the sample to a BCC solid solution; however, no significant change in hardness is observed. Adding Ti decreases the mechanical properties of W alloys [26] and high-entropy alloys [46]. However, addition of up to 7 at% Ti causes no significant change in the hardness of xTi s . The 7Ti s sample is harder than several other refractory, HEAs (Table S1 in Supplementary information).

As shown in Fig. 5(b), the compressive strengths of the xTi s range from 2327 to 2034 MPa and 979e586 MPa at room temperature and 1200 C, respectively. The higher strength of 0Ti s is attributed to the Laves phases [47] observed via XRD (Fig. 2). The remarkable strength of 0Ti s is also attributed to the relatively high V [48] and Cr contents [49] of the sintered sample (Table 1), which promote solid solution strengthening. Ti addition is known to negatively affect the mechanical strengths of W alloys [26] and HEAs [46]. Accordingly, adding 4 at% and 7 at% Ti gradually reduces material strength, as shown in Fig. 5(b). Although the grain refinement due to the addition of Ti gives rise to grain size strengthening [40]. However, solid solution strengthening, which is known to be the main cause of exceptional mechanical properties of HEAs, dominates the mechanical properties of xTis [40]. Slight reductions in the amounts of Cr and V upon transitioning from 0Ti s to 7Ti s (Table 1) also shed light on strength reduction due to solid solution strengthening. Moreover, the elimination of Laves because of sintering promotion via Ti-addition results in relatively low-strength 7Ti s samples. Even after this strength reduction, the BCC solid solution of Ti x WTaVCr that contains 7 at% Ti (denoted as 7Ti s ) remains stronger than several other Ti-containing, refractory, HEAs (Table S1 in Supplementary information). This indicates the potential of this alloy system for future use in challenging applications.

The fracture strains of 0Ti s, 4Ti s , and 7Ti s, in ambient and elevated temperature compression tests were 1e2% with insignificant and abrupt variations. Further addition of Ti (even up to 20 at %) did not cause any significant improvement in strain. This is in contrast to the results obtained for somewhat similar HEAs, NbMoTaW and VNbMoTaW [14]. The addition of 20 at% and 16.6 at% Ti to NbMoTaW and VNbMoTaW to form TiNbMoTaW and TiVNb-MoTaW improved the fracture strains of the alloys from 2.6% to 14.1% and 1.7% to 10.6%, respectively [14]. Chromium and its alloys are inherently brittle [50]. Chromium addition is known to increase the brittleness of refractory HEAs as well [51,52]. Such as the reduction in plastic strain of AlNbTiV and Ti 20 Zr 20 Hf 20 Nb 20 V 20 from 5% to ~29% to 1% and ~5%, respectively, has been reported due to the addition of Cr to from AlCr 0.5 NbTiV [51] and Ti 20 Zr 20 Hf 20 Nb 20 Cr 20 , respectively [52]. The TiNbMoTaW and TiVNbMoTaW HEAs lack in Cr hence improvement in their ductility is observed due to addition of Ti [14]. Whereas xTi s contains significant amount of Cr 22-26 at.%. Therefore, even after improvement in homogeneity of microstructure and reduction in laves phases (as there is no peak of Laves in XRD pattern of 7Ti s ), the effect of Ti on the improvement in ductility is limited [53].

div.head: Oxidation resistance
div.p: Fig. 6 summarizes the oxidation behaviors of xTi s samples with the same surface areas that were subjected to 1000 C air for up to 3 h. The weight gain started at a high rate, but decreased steadily after ~10 min because the oxide layer forms via solid state diffusion [54]. The positive slope of the weight gain curve indicates the absence of metal evaporation during oxidation [54]. The 0Ti s sample gains ~75 mg/cm 2 after 3 h. However, a significant reduction in weight gain is observed in the 7Ti s sample under the same experimental conditions, as shown in Fig. 6.

The effectiveness of Ti in improving the oxidation resistance of xTi s is in line with research conducted by Liu et al. [55], in which the presence of Ti significantly decreased the oxidation resistance of NbCrMoTiAl 0.5 [55]. In xTi s, the addition of 7 at% Ti not only provides the sample with another oxide-forming element, but also produces a near equiatomic single phase with 5 elements (the HEA condition) that exhibits better oxidation resistance than conventional alloys [56] and higher concentrations of oxide layer-forming elements [57]. The 7Ti s alloy exhibits improved oxidation resistance as compare to 0Ti s and shows weight gain up to ~30 mg/cm 2 (45 mg/cm 2 less than 0Ti s ). The weight gain in 7Ti s, which is relatively higher than that of MoWAlCrTi [54], can be reduced further by increasing Ti content [57]. Moreover, the relative amount of V can also be reduced to improve oxidation behavior of xTi s, as reported by Liu et al. [55]. Although Al is sometimes added to refractory HEAs to form a dense, passive oxide layer [55], Al addition is restricted in fusion plasma-facing materials (such as 7Ti s ), in which reduced activation properties are required [58].

Similar to the refractory HEAs reported by Senkov [57], the oxidized 0Ti s and 7Ti s samples form multiple complex oxides. Fig. S4 in Supplementary information identifies some of the oxides, including Ta 8 W 9 O 47 , Ta 0.3 W 0.7 O 2.85, TaO 2 , Ta 2 O 5 , TaO, V 4 O 9 , VO 2 , Cr 5 O 12 , CrO 2 , and CrO. In addition, the 7Ti s sample includes TiO 2 and Ti 3 O 5 . Other complex oxides may also be present [59]. The EDS analysis of the oxidized 0Ti s sample shown in Fig. S5 in Supplementary information reveals a mixed oxide scale up to ~1.16 mm thick. The addition of 7 at% Ti (7Ti s ) increases the concentrations of oxide scale-forming elements [57], which produce less weight gain in 7Ti s than in 0Ti s [57] and generate thinner (~0.22 mm) oxide layers. The expected reductions in diffusivity and oxygen solubility due to heavily alloyed constituents, as described by Senkov reduce the oxidation rate [57].

This study showed that the addition of 7 at% Ti to a Ti x WTaVCr alloy can lead to the formation of a BCC solid solution (>95 vol% by image analysis) via SPS of an elemental powder mixture. The resulting materials exhibit lower activation characteristics and higher strengths and hardnesses (at both room temperature and high temperatures) than several other refractory HEAs, as well as better oxidation resistance than Ti-free samples. Thus, Ti x WTaVCr has the potential for use in high-temperature and plasma-facing applications.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: The effect of Ti on the sintering and properties of Ti x WTaVCr have been explored. Adding 7 at% Ti helped form solid solutions in the majority of the sample via enhanced diffusion. The room temperature and high-temperature compressive yield strengths of the BCC alloy Ti x WTaVCr (x ¼ 7 at%) were higher than those of pure W and several other refractory, HEAs owing to solid solution strengthening and the effects of Cr and V. Improved oxidation resistance was observed at 1000 C owing to the formation of thinner non volatile oxide layers (from ~1.16 mm (0Ti s ) to ~0.22 mm (7Ti s )). The improved mechanical and oxidation properties of Ti x WTaVCr indicate the potential for future use in fusion applications.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 5. Variations in the (a) hardness and (b) compressive yield strength (room temperature and 1200 C) of xTi s with varying compositions.

figure.figDesc: Fig.6. Effect of composition on the isothermal oxidation behaviors of 0Ti s and 7Ti s .

note.p: a x represents the at% of Ti and the subscripts 's' indicate sintered samples.

Waseem, et al., The effect of Ti on the sintering and mechanical properties of refractory high-entropy alloy Ti x WTaVCr fabricated via spark plasma sintering for fusion plasma-facing materials, Materials Chemistry and Physics (2017), http://dx.doi.org/ 10.1016/j.matchemphys.2017.06.054
